Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Exploring Structure-Function Relationships in the Human Airways Through Fluid Mechanics Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1453538
Coletti

The main goal of this CAREER project is to explore how structural features of healthy and diseased airways affect the fluid mechanics of respiration. Since currently used aerosol drug delivery techniques are not efficient, the proposed work would have an impact on targeted drug delivery for respiratory diseases. It could also improve the design and manufacturing of functional implants. The proposed study of both healthy and diseased human airways can offer an understanding of the effect of behaviors such as smoking on the fluid structure interactions of airways. 3D printing of realistic airways significantly increases the broader impact of this research, because it offers a more direct connection to actual airways, and how they are changed by disease. The inclusion of particle deposition is also important because of its potential impact on inhalation therapies. The proposed educational activities combine engineering, physiology, and advanced imaging, such as the development of a 3D printed virtual tour of the lung based on MRI imaging as outreach to the public.

The PI proposes to address a rather significant bio-inspired fluid dynamics problem with an arsenal of state-of-the-art tools: MRI imaging and PIV velocimetry to characterize the flow experimentally and 3D printing for fabricating models to study realistic geometries for healthy and diseased human airways. The experimental system has already been manufactured so that important dimensionless groups in the model are matched to actual behavior in the human airways. The PI proposes to explore the relation between structure, defined as the morphology and the mechanical properties of the airways, and function, defined as the transport of inhaled particles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has explored how structural features of healthy and diseased airways affect the respiratory fluid mechanics, while building an educational program that combines engineering, physiology, and advanced imaging. The societal relevance of this project is evident from the fact that respiratory diseases are among the leading causes of death worldwide, while common strategies for aerosol drug delivery have poor efficiency.

We investigated this topic experimentally, using 3D printed models of the bronchial tree. To characterize the three-dimensional flow, we used a combination of two complementary measurement techniques: Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Particle Image Velocimetry. This allowed to characterize the fluid flow and the transport of particles in bifurcating vessels resembling human bronchi, but also found in the cardiovascular circulation. Both idealized and anatomically realistic models have been considered.

The idealized models, consisting of straight tubular branches symmetrically bifurcating along a plane, show that the air flow favors the central pulmonary airways compared to the lateral ones. In the upper branches, vortical motions are generated at the bifurcation points due to local curvature. Above a certain flow regime, these vortices (which are essential for the mixing and particle transport) propagate into deeper branches and therefore cannot be predicted just by local mechanisms: the whole bronchial architecture needs to be taken into account.

The realistic airway models produce stronger vortices, suggesting that realistic anatomical features generate more lateral dispersion than idealized and symmetric models, and these vortices are stronger during exhalation as compared to inhalation. We also considered anatomical features specifically found in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The subjects with airflow obstruction have smaller airway diameters, and this difference is more significant for subjects that develop severe decline in pulmonary function. The vortical flows were found to be less intense in the subjects with airflow obstruction.  

We then considered oscillatory flow regimes relevant to high-frequency ventilation, a widespread technique of ventilatory support to treat respiratory diseases including COVID-19, which uses higher-than-normal breathing frequencies. We found large regions of flow reversal during the inhalation-exhalation and exhalation-inhalation transitions, and highlighted which transport mechanisms are dominant in such regime.

Finally, we investigated the transport of particles in bifurcating branches, relevant to respiratory flow but also to embolization of cardiovascular vessels. Opposite to the common assumption, we found that the particles distribution is fundamentally different from the volumetric flow partition. In fact, the amount of delivered particles varies substantially between adjacent branches even when the flow is uniformly distributed. The particle distribution is rooted in their different pathways, which in turn are linked to their release origin in the mother branch.

The outcomes of this project find application in early diagnosis of airway diseases and targeted drug delivery. The topic has offered an ideal framework to introduce engineering concepts to young students through something as natural as breathing. Several African American K‐12 students were specifically engaged in a learning‐through‐research process, during which they learned about fluid mechanics and physiology.
